item.title: Truthiness, Damned Truthiness, and Statistics
item.description:
• Read
  • Suggestions
    • Questions to reflect on

Read

  • Chapters 5-6 in James McDavid, Program Evaluation and Performance Measurement

  • Chapters 3-5 in Tony Albano, Introduction to Educational and Psychological Measurement Using R

Note: Firefox appears to have some problems rendering the formulas in the text properly. Google Chrome, Safari, and Tor do not appear to have this problem. With that said, I am not concerned whether you know a formula or not, rather I want you to understand the general idea so please take your time on Chapter 5!

Suggestions

Take some time to review or get a first look at some basic statistics. Again, I do not care if you can memorize a formula. We have these things called books and the Internet to get those. Rather if you can understand what’s going on and when to use a method (e.g. when is it more appropriate to take the mean, median, or mode of a sample).

  • The statistics videos over at Crash Course are fantastic and pretty entertaining. If interested, you can see the entire list of Crash Course: Statistics series by clicking here. The example video below is on sampling and bias.

  • A good resource for doing foundational level statistics in R, check out Learning statistics with R: A tutorial for psychology students and other beginners which is part of an ongoing effort to bring statistics with R to the masses.

Questions to reflect on1

  • What do descriptive statistics really tell us?
  • What can’t descriptive statistics tell us?
  • How are both assessment and evaluation used in CTT (classical test theory)?
  • Why is reliability important?
  • How is reliability used in analyzing qualitative data?

Please submit your narrative to eCampus.

  1. These reflection items can be integrated into this week’s reflection which is item #2 in the Exercise II Task.↩︎

item.title: Pirates Cause Global Warming
item.description:
• Read
  • Suggestions
    • Questions to reflect on

Read

  • Chapters 8-9 in James McDavid, Program Evaluation and Performance Measurement. While not required Chapter 7 is on economic evaluation, that is the content is solely focused on assessing whether the potential or actual benefits from interventions are greater than the projected or existing loss in benefits from a reduction in other programs. If the idea of something like a cost-benefit analysis interests you, please read this.

  • Chapters 6-7 in Tony Albano, Introduction to Educational and Psychological Measurement Using R

Note: Firefox appears to have some problems rendering the formulas in the text properly. Google Chrome, Safari, and Tor do not appear to have this problem. With that said, Chapter 7 is somewhat dense and you are not expected to memorize formulas. Get the basic idea of what an IRT is and what it is used for and ask questions as needed!

Suggestions

Next week we cover Item Response Theory (IRT) in greater detail. While Chapter 7 in Albano’s online text is a needed read, it is a bit difficult to fully comprehend at first so we’ll be emphasizing the procedural aspects of conducting one. If you want a grounded conceptual (not statistical or mathematical) introduction, check out Karon F. Cook’s short 6-part series. She does a really good job bringing a relatively high level concept down to Earth.

Questions to reflect on

This week first head over to the new version and old version of Spurious Correlations: the often hilarious and always ridiculous examples of why correlation doesn’t imply causation. Pick one out, paste it into a word document and then write a one paragraph narrative on

  • why you chose the one that you did?
  • do you think correlation is ever enough? what is that point?
  • how do you think correlation is tied to measurement?

Stuck? Please take a look at this read of some common survey design mistakes that lead to all kinds of measurement errors.

item.title: Factors! FACTORS! They’re Everywhere! Your Firearms Are Useless Against Them!
item.description:
• Read
  • Suggestions
    • Questions to reflect on

Read

  • Chapters 10-12 in James McDavid, Program Evaluation and Performance Measurement.

  • Chapter 10 in Tony Albano, Introduction to Educational and Psychological Measurement Using R. There is not a hint of syntax in this chapter, rather its just a decent summary of the primary items related to measurement. Please skim it over to see if you have compartmentalized the ideas related to each.

Suggestions

Start working on your final proposal. If you want feedback on some chunks of your narrative (at most three paragraphs unless we have discussed prior), please send them along. I’ll provide this on a first come-first serve basis.

Questions to reflect on

For this week, here are some possible questions to mull around:

  • What can a factor analysis do when assessing surveys?
  • What types of questions can a factor analysis answer?
  • What do the different types of factor analyses do and how could they inform specific parts of an questionnaire?
